awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID--The Influence of Terrain on Tornado Characteristics Following the 10-11 December 2021 Tornado Outbreak
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent observational and modeling studies of the influence of terrain on tornadoes have universally cited the need for further research. The 10-11 December 2021 tornado outbreak provides a unique and valuable opportunity to fill knowledge gaps by conducting both aerial and ground evaluations in forested areas damaged by strong tornadoes that passed over complex terrain. The primary objective of this Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project is to provide a preliminary evaluation of the influence of terrain on tornado characteristics. The project team will conduct a high-resolution assessment of forest damage and terrain based on aerial imagery and ground surveys, and then develop a quantitative comparison of damage levels and tornado characteristics across terrain features using GIS tools, machine learning, and analytical vortex models. Results will inform simple engineering models to assess risk to the built and natural environment and will enhance general awareness of the threat of tornadoes in areas where the public may not recognize the dangers. 

Existing research into the influence of terrain on tornado characteristics has substantial limitations, including a limited number of case studies, idealized simulation parameters, and inconclusive or contradictory results. A novel research approach will test the hypotheses that 1) tornado intensity decreases (increases) as the vortex moves uphill (downhill), 2) higher (lower) surface roughness leads to stronger (weaker) near-surface winds, and 3) terrain features can deflect the path of a tornado in predictable ways. This approach employs the structure-from-motion (SfM) photogrammetric range imaging technique to provide an extremely high-resolution characterization of both terrain and treefall at centimeter scales through the development of 2-D orthomosaics and 3-D point clouds that include information on the size, location, and disposition of hundreds of thousands of trees. The data collected here and the subsequent analyses will help the meteorological and engineering communities to move toward scientific consensus regarding the influence of terrain on tornadic circulations and will allow for new and more detailed research studies. Although large eddy simulation (LES) tests are beyond the scope of the work, the data collected here will also enable next-generation LES studies with far greater realism than has previously been possible.

por.por_cntn:
This project has undertaken an extensive and detailed analysis of tornado damage to forest, in an effort to understand how tornadoes interact with terrain by examining the forest damage “signature”.  Extremely high-resolution (roughly 2 cm) orthoimages and structure-from-motion point clouds were obtained across two large tornado tracks in the Land Between the Lakes National Recreation Area on the Kentucky-Tennessee border; these images and point clouds over a total of 46.2 km2 and 45,000 images and are the most extensive remote analysis of forest tornado damage known to the authors.  The project has been testing the following three hypotheses: (1) Tornado intensity decreases as the vortex moves uphill and increases as it moves downhill. (2) Higher surface roughness leads to stronger near-surface winds, while lower roughness results in weaker winds. (3) Terrain features can deflect the path of a tornado in predictable ways.

 

              Analyses are still underway, but results to date suggest that terrain indeed has a strong influence on patterns of tornado damage, as shown by forest treefall patterns. Severity of forest damage in the study areas was greater in valleys than on hilltops or ridges, perhaps because of the taller tree canopy in the low areas.  The more northern of the two tornado tracks was larger and more intense, and the intensity of forest damage was greater on the right side of the tornado path. The project has not yet discovered evidence of an effect of surface roughness on near-surface wind intensity, but there are indications that in some circumstances the tornado path is deflected by terrain in a way that causes the tornado path to track along valleys. 

 

              As part of the effort to analyze the very extensive imagery, two members of the team (Nasimi and Wood) have developed a novel deep learning model to detect post-tornado treefall, incorporating physics and statistical filtering as well as tree taper for determining fall direction.  This is the foundation of a software tool, TreeAID, which is in beta testing prior to public release, and which will provide valuable automated treefall analysis for the meteorological community.

 

Peer-reviewed papers already published:

Nasimi M., and R.L. Wood. 2024.  Using Deep Learning and Advanced Image Processing for Automated Estimation of Tornado-Induced Treefall. Remote Sensing. 16(7), 1130; https://doi.org/ 10.3390/rs16071130.

Presentations at meetings and conferences to share findings:

Wood R.L., C.J. Peterson, M. Nasimi, S.M. Moon, C. Dev, C.M. Godfrey, and F.T. Lombardo.  2024. Evaluating Tornado Intensity and Interactions with Terrain via Remote Sensing of Treefall, Part 1: Overview. 104th Annual Meeting of the American Meteorological Society, Baltimore, MD, February 1, 2024.
